chunks.title: Written Contract Requirements
chunks.key_rule: All rental agreements must be in writing to be enforceable
chunks.expat_implication: Verbal agreements are not legally binding. Always insist on a written contract in a language you understand before paying any money.

chunks.title: Contract Language and Translation
chunks.key_rule: Contracts must be understandable to both parties
chunks.expat_implication: You have the right to a translation if you don't understand German. Don't sign anything you can't fully comprehend.

chunks.title: Fixed vs Indefinite Term Contracts
chunks.key_rule: Fixed-term contracts require specific justification
chunks.expat_implication: Landlords need valid reasons for fixed terms (e.g., personal use). Indefinite contracts offer more flexibility but require proper notice.

chunks.title: Security Deposit Limits
chunks.key_rule: Maximum 3 months' net rent as security deposit
chunks.expat_implication: Landlords cannot demand more than 3 months' rent, even for expats. This applies whether you're German or foreign.

chunks.title: Deposit Return Process
chunks.key_rule: Landlord must return deposit within reasonable time after inspection
chunks.expat_implication: Document condition thoroughly at move-in with photos/videos. This protects you from unfair deductions when leaving.

chunks.title: Deposit Interest Requirements
chunks.key_rule: Landlord may need to pay interest on long-term deposits
chunks.expat_implication: For stays over 3 years, check if your deposit earns interest. This varies by state but can affect your total housing cost.

chunks.title: Cold Rent vs Warm Rent
chunks.key_rule: Rent consists of base rent (Kaltmiete) plus utilities (Nebenkosten)
chunks.expat_implication: Understand what's included in your utilities. Heating, water, and building maintenance are typically included; electricity and internet usually aren't.

chunks.title: Rent Increase Limits
chunks.key_rule: Rent increases are capped at 20% over 3 years (Mietpreisbremse)
chunks.expat_implication: In many cities, rent cannot exceed local rates by more than 10%. Check if your area has rent control - this protects you from price gouging.

chunks.title: Modernization Increases
chunks.key_rule: Landlords can increase rent by 8-11% for major renovations
chunks.expat_implication: If your landlord renovates, they can raise rent but there are limits. You have the right to see documentation of renovation costs.

chunks.title: Indexed Rent Clauses
chunks.key_rule: Rent can be tied to inflation index with specific conditions
chunks.expat_implication: Be wary of indexed rent contracts. While they protect landlords from inflation, they can lead to significant increases over time.

chunks.title: Landlord Repair Responsibilities
chunks.key_rule: Landlord responsible for structural repairs and major systems
chunks.expat_implication: Heating, plumbing, roof, and building structure are landlord's responsibility. Don't let landlords push these costs onto you.

chunks.title: Tenant Minor Repair Obligation
chunks.key_rule: Tenants responsible for minor repairs up to €100-150
chunks.expat_implication: Small repairs like changing lightbulbs or fixing a dripping tap are your responsibility. Keep receipts for any repairs you pay for.

chunks.title: Heating System Standards
chunks.key_rule: Landlord must ensure adequate heating (minimum 20-22°C)
chunks.expat_implication: If your apartment is too cold, landlord must fix heating within reasonable time. Document temperatures if there are issues.

chunks.title: Cosmetic Repairs Timeline
chunks.key_rule: Who pays for cosmetic repairs depends on contract and duration
chunks.expat_implication: Painting and wallpapering rules vary. In long-term rentals, tenants often handle cosmetic repairs, but this must be in contract.

chunks.title: Quiet Enjoyment Rights
chunks.key_rule: Tenants have right to peaceful enjoyment of property
chunks.expat_implication: Landlord cannot enter without notice except emergencies. 24-48 hours notice is standard for non-urgent visits.

chunks.title: Landlord Access Rules
chunks.key_rule: Landlord must provide reasonable notice before entering
chunks.expat_implication: You can refuse entry without proper notice. Emergency access is allowed but must be justified.

chunks.title: Subletting Permission
chunks.key_rule: Subletting requires landlord's written consent
chunks.expat_implication: Get sublet permission in writing before signing. Landlords can't unreasonably refuse if you have legitimate need.

chunks.title: Housing Protection Benefits
chunks.key_rule: Social housing offers additional protections
chunks.expat_implication: If you qualify for social housing, you get extra protection against eviction and rent increases. Check eligibility requirements.

chunks.title: Tenant Notice Period
chunks.key_rule: Standard 3-month notice period for tenants
chunks.expat_implication: Notice must be given by the 3rd working day of the month to be effective at end of quarter. Plan your departure carefully.

chunks.title: Landlord Notice Requirements
chunks.key_rule: Landlords need valid reasons and longer notice periods
chunks.expat_implication: Landlords can't terminate without good cause. Notice periods vary: 3 months for 5 years, 6 months for 8 years, 9 months for 10+ years.

chunks.title: Special Termination Rights
chunks.key_rule: Early termination possible for job loss, illness, or military service
chunks.expat_implication: If you lose your job or have health issues, you may terminate early with proper documentation. This is crucial for expats facing sudden repatriation.

chunks.title: Moving Out Process
chunks.key_rule: Handover protocol must be followed precisely
chunks.expat_implication: Schedule handover inspection, document everything, and get written confirmation of condition. This affects your deposit return.

chunks.title: Utility Bill Settlement
chunks.key_rule: Annual settlement of utility costs with potential refunds or additional payments
chunks.expat_implication: Keep all utility bills. You may get money back if you used less than estimated, or pay more if you exceeded estimates.

chunks.title: Heating Cost Allocation
chunks.key_rule: Heating costs must be fairly distributed among tenants
chunks.expat_implication: Understand how heating costs are calculated. New buildings must have individual metering for better cost control.

chunks.title: Inheritance of Tenancy
chunks.key_rule: Family members can inherit tenancy rights
chunks.expat_implication: If you pass away, your spouse or children can take over the lease. This provides stability for families in difficult times.

chunks.title: Sale of Property
chunks.key_rule: New owner must honor existing lease
chunks.expat_implication: If your landlord sells the building, your lease remains valid with same terms. New owner can't terminate or change terms without cause.

chunks.title: Force Majeure Events
chunks.key_rule: Extraordinary circumstances may affect obligations
chunks.expat_implication: Pandemics, natural disasters, or other force majeure events may temporarily suspend certain obligations. Document everything carefully.
